results.title: ‘Jurassic World Dominion’ Review: Extinction Rebellion
results.abstract: Things get very hectic in the last episode of this trilogy, which brings back familiar faces (Jeff Goldblum, Laura Dern, Sam Neill) along with the usual dinosaurs.

multimedia.caption: Don’t look up: From left, the “Jurassic Park” veterans Jeff Goldblum, Sam Neill and Laura Dern with Bryce Dallas Howard, Chris Pratt, Isabella Sermon and DeWanda Wise in “Jurassic Park Dominion.”
Don’t look up: From left, the “Jurassic Park” veterans Jeff Goldblum, Sam Neill and Laura Dern with Bryce Dallas Howard, Chris Pratt, Isabella Sermon and DeWanda Wise in “Jurassic Park Dominion.”
Don’t look up: From left, the “Jurassic Park” veterans Jeff Goldblum, Sam Neill and Laura Dern with Bryce Dallas Howard, Chris Pratt, Isabella Sermon and DeWanda Wise in “Jurassic Park Dominion.”

results.title: John Waters, an Auteur of Trash, Would Like to Thank the Academy
results.abstract: Curators from the new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures rummaged through his Baltimore home to plan an exhibition on Waters and his cult films.

multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

results.title: The Tribeca Festival Returns in Full Bloom
results.abstract: The springtime extravaganza returns with another sweeping bill of fare. We trawled through the slate so you can savor the gems.

multimedia.caption: Jennifer Lopez in the documentary “Halftime.”
Jennifer Lopez in the documentary “Halftime.”
Jennifer Lopez in the documentary “Halftime.”

results.title: ‘Lost Illusions’ Review: The Sweet Smell of Success
results.abstract: Xavier Giannoli’s headlong adaptation of a Balzac novel paints a timely picture of literary ambition and media corruption in 19th-century France.

multimedia.caption: A writer and his editor: Benjamin Voisin, left, and Vincent Lacoste in “Lost Illusions.”
A writer and his editor: Benjamin Voisin, left, and Vincent Lacoste in “Lost Illusions.”
A writer and his editor: Benjamin Voisin, left, and Vincent Lacoste in “Lost Illusions.”

results.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: From pensive dramas about androids to upbeat anime about virtual pop stars, this month’s selection of films has creative range.

multimedia.caption: From left, Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith, Malea Emma Tjandrawidjaja and Justin H. Min in “After Yang.”
From left, Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith, Malea Emma Tjandrawidjaja and Justin H. Min in “After Yang.”
From left, Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith, Malea Emma Tjandrawidjaja and Justin H. Min in “After Yang.”

results.title: A Queer-Film Historian Discusses Movies That Provoke
results.abstract: Elizabeth Purchell, who has programmed a series on the documentaries of Rosa von Praunheim, sees Pride Month as a chance to discover, and uncover, the past.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Transexual Menace,” one of the six documentaries in “Revolt of the Perverts,” a new Rosa von Praunheim retrospective at Brooklyn’s Spectacle Theater.
A scene from “Transexual Menace,” one of the six documentaries in “Revolt of the Perverts,” a new Rosa von Praunheim retrospective at Brooklyn’s Spectacle Theater.
A scene from “Transexual Menace,” one of the six documentaries in “Revolt of the Perverts,” a new Rosa von Praunheim retrospective at Brooklyn’s Spectacle Theater.

results.title: The Real Stars of the ‘Jurassic’ Films? Friends, Not Dinosaurs.
results.abstract: When Laura Dern, Sam Neill and Jeff Goldblum reprised their roles for the new sequel, they quickly refound the chemistry they had in the 1993 blockbuster.

results.title: ‘Hustle’ Review: Put Me In, N.B.A. Executive!
results.abstract: Adam Sandler and the Utah Jazz player Juancho Hernangómez lead an unsentimental sports drama in which success is tenuous and one mistake can derail a dream.

multimedia.caption: Juancho Hernangómez, left, and Adam Sandler in “Hustle.”
Juancho Hernangómez, left, and Adam Sandler in “Hustle.”
Juancho Hernangómez, left, and Adam Sandler in “Hustle.”

results.title: Five Influences on the Horror Film ‘Watcher’
results.abstract: Chloe Okuno’s bone-chilling debut feature is about a woman unnerved by a man watching her from an apartment window. The director shared what was in her head while assembling it.

multimedia.caption: Maika Monroe in “Watcher.”
Maika Monroe in “Watcher.”
Maika Monroe in “Watcher.”

results.title: Two Men of the Jungle Meet in Herzog’s First Novel
results.abstract: In “The Twilight World,” the filmmaker Werner Herzog vividly reconstructs the personal war of Hiroo Onoda, who stayed in the jungle for years after World War II ended.

results.title: Ariana DeBose on Hosting the Tonys: ‘Whatever We Do Is Going to Be Fun’
results.abstract: The Broadway ensemble member turned Oscar winner vows that the ceremony will celebrate the often unsung actors who have stepped in so often during the pandemic.

multimedia.caption: Ariana DeBose (at the recent Costume Institute gala) has been in six Broadway shows and is hosting the Tony Awards for the first time.
multimedia.copyright: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

results.title: ‘I’m Charlie Walker’ Review: More Wink Than Wallop
results.abstract: The actor Mike Colter imbues Charlie with cool savvy in this movie about a Black trucker in the ’70s who goes up against the white establishment.

multimedia.caption: Safiya Fredericks and Mike Colter in “I’m Charlie Walker.”
Safiya Fredericks and Mike Colter in “I’m Charlie Walker.”
Safiya Fredericks and Mike Colter in “I’m Charlie Walker.”

results.title: In a First for Broadway, a Theater Will Be Renamed for Lena Horne
results.abstract: Horne, a renowned singer and activist, will be the first Black woman to have a theater named after her once the Brooks Atkinson is renamed.

multimedia.caption: Lena Horne appeared in five Broadway shows, including “Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music,” which in the early 1980s had a run at the Nederlander Theater.
Lena Horne appeared in five Broadway shows, including “Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music,” which in the early 1980s had a run at the Nederlander Theater.
Lena Horne appeared in five Broadway shows, including “Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music,” which in the early 1980s had a run at the Nederlander Theater.

results.title: ‘The Walk’ Review: Two Families So Far Apart
results.abstract: This sentimental drama about an upstanding cop caught up in the 1974 school desegregation conflict in Boston recycles tired white-savior clichés.

multimedia.caption: Justin Chatwin in “The Walk,” directed by Daniel Adams.
Justin Chatwin in “The Walk,” directed by Daniel Adams.
Justin Chatwin in “The Walk,” directed by Daniel Adams.

results.title: ‘The Janes’ Review: Taking Matters Into Their Own Hands
results.abstract: This HBO documentary spotlights the women activists who banded together to form Jane, a clandestine group providing safe abortions in the years before Roe v. Wade.

multimedia.caption: Members of the Jane Collective, an activist group that helped provide safe abortion in the years before Roe v. Wade.
Members of the Jane Collective, an activist group that helped provide safe abortion in the years before Roe v. Wade.
Members of the Jane Collective, an activist group that helped provide safe abortion in the years before Roe v. Wade.

results.title: ‘Ninja Badass’ Review: Kill Bad Guys, Save Hot Babes, Look Silly
results.abstract: Ryan Harrison, an auteur of the gross, includes sight gags like puppies in blenders in this tedious action comedy.

multimedia.caption: Ryan Harrison in “Ninja Badass,” which he also wrote and directed.
Ryan Harrison in “Ninja Badass,” which he also wrote and directed.
Ryan Harrison in “Ninja Badass,” which he also wrote and directed.

results.title: ‘Tahara’ Review: Hierarchy at a Hebrew-School Funeral
results.abstract: Rachel Sennott and Madeline Grey DeFreece star in a canny portrait of teenage insensitivity and sexuality amid a tragedy.

multimedia.caption: Madeline Grey DeFreece, left, and Rachel Sennott in “Tahara.”
Madeline Grey DeFreece, left, and Rachel Sennott in “Tahara.”
Madeline Grey DeFreece, left, and Rachel Sennott in “Tahara.”

results.title: ‘1982’ Review: When War Canceled School
results.abstract: This film from the director Oualid Mouaness is inspired by his memories of being a child during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon that year.

multimedia.caption: Mohamad Dalli and Gia Madi in “1982.”
Mohamad Dalli and Gia Madi in “1982.”
Mohamad Dalli and Gia Madi in “1982.”

results.title: ‘The Lost Girls’ Review: Wendy’s Telling of Peter Pan
results.abstract: In her second feature film, the director Livia De Paolis awkwardly tries to comment on the gender dynamics in J.M Barrie’s classic.

multimedia.caption: Emily Carey and Louis Partridge, as Peter Pan, in “Lost Girls.”
Emily Carey and Louis Partridge, as Peter Pan, in “Lost Girls.”
Emily Carey and Louis Partridge, as Peter Pan, in “Lost Girls.”

results.title: ‘Small Town Wisconsin’ Review: A Father-Son Trip Goes Awry
results.abstract: A major-league farewell journey turns into an adventure for this dad who is losing shared custody.

results.title: Harvey Weinstein Facing Indecent Assault Charges in Britain
results.abstract: British prosecutors said they authorized criminal charges against Mr. Weinstein for an incident in 1996.

multimedia.caption: Harvey Weinstein arriving at a Manhattan courthouse in 2020.
Harvey Weinstein arriving at a Manhattan courthouse in 2020.
Harvey Weinstein arriving at a Manhattan courthouse in 2020.

results.title: Werner Herzog’s Fever Dreams
results.abstract: The filmmaker behind “Grizzly Man” and “Fitzcarraldo” makes a late-career foray into fiction with his new book, “The Twilight World.” He feels he has finally found his medium.

multimedia.caption: “None of my characters are extreme nor strange,” Werner Herzog said. “They are dignified human beings, and they take the struggle of life as it’s thrown at them.”
multimedia.copyright: Robbie Lawrence for The New York Times

results.title: Is It Finally Twilight for the Theater’s Sacred Monsters?
results.abstract: Many of the “great men” who helped America create its classics, its institutions and its own acting style were tyrants. We need to cut them loose.
des_facet: The Method: How the Twentieth Century Learned to Act (Book)

results.title: ‘A Sexplanation’ Review: Sex Education Fit for a Classroom
results.abstract: The director Alex Liu explores the politics and culture of sex ed in the United States while confronting his own shame around sexuality.

results.title: Ruth Negga Thinks Lady Macbeth Is Misunderstood
results.abstract: The actress, nominated for a Tony Award for her magnetic performance in “Macbeth,” is drawn to female characters who challenge the status quo.

results.title: The Costume Designer at the Center of the Universes
results.abstract: With the success of the film “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” the work of Shirley Kurata is in demand, but her personal style has always had its own fans.

multimedia.caption: The costume designer Shirley Kurata, shown here in Los Angeles’s Chinatown, describes herself as a “creative collaborator.” She has dressed Billie Eilish, Tierra Whack, Lena Dunham, Jenny Lewis and Pharrell Williams.

results.title: With ‘Neptune Frost,’ How to Make an Afrofuturist Sci-Fi Musical
results.abstract: What does technological progress look like to those exploited to achieve it? The co-directors Saul Williams and Anisia Uzeyman discuss their unusual film.

results.title: For Joel Kim Booster, Making ‘Fire Island’ Was a Real Trip
results.abstract: The writer and star of “Fire Island” reflects on making the rare romantic comedy that puts gay Asian American men at its center.

multimedia.caption: Joel Kim Booster at Akbar in Los Angeles. He said that before filming started, he thought, “This is either going to change my life or it’s going to be the biggest flop of my career.”
